reason: The claim that p^{(1)} has simple real roots is stated as following from 'Rolle's theorem and the interlacing property,' but this is insufficient. Rolle's theorem only guarantees at least one root in each gap between consecutive roots of p, hence at least n-1 real roots of p'. It does NOT guarantee simplicity. The simplicity of roots of p' (when p has all simple real roots) requires an additional argument: if p'(c) = p''(c) = 0 with c between consecutive roots of p, then p(c) \!= 0 and the logarithmic derivative identity d/dx(p'/p) = -sum 1/(x-a_i)^2 evaluated at c gives p''(c)/p(c) = -sum 1/(c-a_i)^2 < 0, contradicting p''(c) = 0. This standard but nontrivial fact should be stated explicitly or cited.
